riddle.question: I am a king of fruits, yellow and sweet. In Indian summers, I'm the favorite treat. What am I?
riddle.hint: I am yellow and have a large seed.
riddle.explanation: The mango is the national fruit of India and is widely loved during the summer season.

riddle.question: I have a thumb and four fingers, but I am not alive. What am I?
riddle.hint: You wear me to keep your hand warm.
riddle.explanation: A glove is designed to fit a hand, including the thumb and fingers.

riddle.question: I am white when I am dirty, and black when I am clean. What am I?
riddle.hint: Your teacher writes on me.
riddle.explanation: A blackboard is black until you write on it with white chalk.

riddle.question: I have a colorful tail that I spread like a fan. I am the national bird of Bharat. Who am I?
riddle.hint: I am known for my beautiful blue and green feathers.
riddle.explanation: The Indian Peacock is the national bird known for its beautiful plumage.

riddle.question: If you feed me, I live. If you give me water, I die. What am I?
riddle.hint: I am hot and produce light.
riddle.explanation: Fire needs fuel to burn but is extinguished by water.

riddle.question: I have many keys but can't open a single lock. What am I?
riddle.hint: I have black and white keys that produce music.
riddle.explanation: A piano has musical keys, not locking keys.

riddle.question: I am an Indian monument of love, made of white marble in Agra. What is my name?
riddle.hint: Shah Jahan built me for his wife.
riddle.explanation: The Taj Mahal was built by Shah Jahan in memory of Mumtaz Mahal.

riddle.question: What starts with T, ends with T, and has T in it?
riddle.hint: I am used for brewing and pouring a hot beverage.
riddle.explanation: The word 'Teapot' starts and ends with 'T' and contains 'tea'.

riddle.question: I have a face and two hands, but no arms or legs. What am I?
riddle.hint: I help you tell the time.
riddle.explanation: A clock has a face and hour/minute hands.

riddle.question: I am the festival of lights in India. I celebrate the victory of good over evil. What am I?
riddle.hint: We light diyas and burst crackers during this time.
riddle.explanation: Diwali (Deepavali) is the most prominent festival of lights in India.

riddle.question: I am the "Pink City" of India. What is my name?
riddle.hint: I am the historic capital of Rajasthan.
riddle.explanation: Jaipur is known as the Pink City due to the color of its buildings.

riddle.question: What has to be broken before you can use it?
riddle.hint: You need me for an omelette.
riddle.explanation: You must break the shell of an egg to cook or eat it.

riddle.question: I am tall when I am young, and short when I am old. What am I?
riddle.hint: I melt as I burn to give light.
riddle.explanation: A candle burns down and becomes shorter over time.

riddle.question: Which month of the year has 28 days?
riddle.hint: Don't stop at just February.
riddle.explanation: Every month has at least 28 days.

riddle.question: I am full of holes but still hold water. What am I?
riddle.hint: I am used in the kitchen or bath to absorb liquids.
riddle.explanation: A sponge's porous structure allows it to absorb and hold water.

riddle.question: I am an Indian game of tag and chasing. It's played in a court. What is it?
riddle.hint: Players sit and run in a line in this game.
riddle.explanation: Kho-Kho is a popular traditional tag game in India.

riddle.question: What question can you never answer 'yes' to?
riddle.hint: If you were doing this, you couldn't hear the question.
riddle.explanation: If you are asleep, you cannot respond to the question.

riddle.question: What is always in front of you but can't be seen?
riddle.hint: It's what happens after now.
riddle.explanation: The future is what lies ahead of us in time.

riddle.question: I have a neck but no head. What am I?
riddle.hint: I am meant to hold liquids like water or juice.
riddle.explanation: A bottle has a narrow part called a neck.

riddle.question: I am the "Spice Garden of India". Which state am I?
riddle.hint: I am located on the tropical Malabar Coast.
riddle.explanation: Kerala is famous for its spices like black pepper and cardamom.

riddle.question: What can you break, even if you never pick it up or touch it?
riddle.hint: It happens when you don't do what you said you would.
riddle.explanation: A promise is broken when you don't keep your word.

riddle.question: What goes up but never comes down?
riddle.hint: It's measured in years since you were born.
riddle.explanation: Your age only increases as time passes.

riddle.question: I have cities, but no houses. I have mountains, but no trees. I have water, but no fish. What am I?
riddle.hint: I am a flat representation of the world.
riddle.explanation: A map represents these things but doesn't contain the physical objects.

riddle.question: I am the traditional Indian dress worn by women, usually 6 yards long. What am I?
riddle.hint: It's an elegant, draped fabric garment.
riddle.explanation: The Saree is a traditional Indian garment made of a long piece of fabric.

riddle.question: What has legs, but doesn't walk?
riddle.hint: You sit around me to eat or work.
riddle.explanation: A table has four legs for support but is a stationary object.

riddle.question: What kind of band never plays music?
riddle.hint: I am elastic and used to hold things together.
riddle.explanation: A rubber band is used to hold things together, not for music.

riddle.question: I am the holy river of India, believed to wash away sins. What is my name?
riddle.hint: I am also known as the Ganges.
riddle.explanation: The Ganges is the most sacred river in Hinduism.

riddle.question: What has many teeth, but cannot bite?
riddle.hint: You use me to style your hair.
riddle.explanation: A comb has "teeth" to untangle hair but isn't alive.

riddle.question: What goes up and down but doesn't move?
riddle.hint: A set of steps in a building.
riddle.explanation: A staircase leads up or down but stays fixed in place.

riddle.question: I am the Father of the Nation in India. I preached non-violence. Who am I?
riddle.hint: He is also affectionately called 'Bapu'.
riddle.explanation: Mahatma Gandhi led India's independence movement through non-violent civil disobedience.

riddle.question: I start with 'P' and end with 'E' and have thousands of letters. What am I?
riddle.hint: Every neighborhood has one for mailing packages.
riddle.explanation: A Post Office contains thousands of letters to be delivered.

riddle.question: I have a single horn but I am not a unicorn. I live in Kaziranga, Assam. What am I?
riddle.hint: I am a large gray animal with thick skin.
riddle.explanation: The Great One-Horned Rhinoceros is native to Assam, India.

riddle.question: What word is spelled incorrectly in every dictionary?
riddle.hint: Look at the word within the question itself.
riddle.explanation: The word "incorrectly" is spelled as "incorrectly".

riddle.question: I am a famous Indian board game where you use luck to climb and avoid being swallowed. What am I?
riddle.hint: It used to be called 'Moksha Patam'.
riddle.explanation: Snakes and Ladders originated in ancient India as Moksha Patam.

riddle.question: What is so fragile that saying its name breaks it?
riddle.hint: It's the absence of sound.
riddle.explanation: When you speak the word "silence", you have broken the state of being silent.

riddle.question: I am an Indian scientist who discovered that plants have feelings and life. Who am I?
riddle.hint: He invented the Crescograph.
riddle.explanation: Sir J.C. Bose proved that plants respond to stimuli much like animals.

riddle.question: What can travel around the world while staying in a corner?
riddle.hint: You lick it and stick it on an envelope.
riddle.explanation: A postage stamp stays in the corner of an envelope as it travels globally.

riddle.question: I am the Indian city where the tea is famous and hills are blue. What am I?
riddle.hint: It's a hill station in West Bengal.
riddle.explanation: Darjeeling is world-renowned for its tea and scenic hill views.

riddle.question: The more of this there is, the less you see. What is it?
riddle.hint: The opposite of light.
riddle.explanation: Darkness obscures vision, so more darkness means less visibility.

riddle.question: I am the sport where India has won 8 Olympic Gold medals. What am I?
riddle.hint: It's played with a curved stick and a ball.
riddle.explanation: India's men's hockey team was dominant in the Olympics for decades.

riddle.question: I follow you all day long, but when the sun goes down, I am gone. What am I?
riddle.hint: I am a dark shape made by your body.
riddle.explanation: A shadow is formed by blocking light and disappears in the dark.

riddle.question: I am the Indian state named the "Land of Five Rivers". What am I?
riddle.hint: Famous for Bhangra and its fertile fields.
riddle.explanation: Punjab means "The land of five waters" (Beas, Jhelum, Chenab, Ravi, Sutlej).

riddle.question: What bank has no money?
riddle.hint: It's where the water meets the land.
riddle.explanation: The side of a river is called a bank.

riddle.question: I am the mathematical concept discovered in India by Aryabhatta. What am I?
riddle.hint: It represents nothingness but is very powerful.
riddle.explanation: The concept of zero as a number was refined by ancient Indian mathematicians.

riddle.question: What belongs to you, but others use it more than you do?
riddle.hint: It's the word people use to get your attention.
riddle.explanation: You are called by your name more than you call yourself.

riddle.question: I am the Indian harvest festival of Tamil Nadu, involving boiling rice. What am I?
riddle.hint: It's a four-day festival celebrated in South India.
riddle.explanation: Pongal is a four-day harvest festival celebrated by Tamilians.

riddle.question: What has a head and a tail but no body?
riddle.hint: You flip me to make a decision.
riddle.explanation: The two sides of a coin are called head and tail.

riddle.question: I am the animal that represents the strength of India and is our National Animal. What am I?
riddle.hint: The Royal Bengal variety lives in the Sunderbans.
riddle.explanation: The Royal Bengal Tiger is India's national animal.

riddle.question: What gets wetter the more it dries?
riddle.hint: You use it after swimming or showering.
riddle.explanation: A towel dries you, but in the process, it becomes wet.

riddle.question: I am the first Indian to travel to space. Who am I?
riddle.hint: When asked how India looks from space, he said "Sare Jahan Se Achha".
riddle.explanation: Rakesh Sharma flew aboard the Soviet Soyuz T-11 in 1984.

riddle.question: I have branches, but no fruit, trunk or leaves. What am I?
riddle.hint: It’s a place where you keep your savings.
riddle.explanation: A bank has multiple locations or branches.

riddle.question: I am the largest democratic body in India, where laws are made. What am I?
riddle.hint: The building is located in New Delhi.
riddle.explanation: The Parliament of India is the supreme legislative body.

riddle.question: What has hands but cannot clap?
riddle.hint: I have a face and I tell you when it’s lunch time.
riddle.explanation: A clock has hour and minute hands but not biological ones.

riddle.question: I am the Indian city known as the "Garden City". What is my name?
riddle.hint: It's the capital of Karnataka and a tech hub.
riddle.explanation: Bengaluru is known for its many parks and green spaces.

riddle.question: David's father has three sons: Snap, Crackle, and... ?
riddle.hint: The answer is already in the question.
riddle.explanation: David is the third son mentioned.

riddle.question: I am the Indian freedom fighter known as "Iron Man of India". Who am I?
riddle.hint: He worked hard to unite the princely states.
riddle.explanation: Sardar Vallabhbhai Patel integrated the princely states into India.

riddle.question: What invention lets you look right through a wall?
riddle.hint: It's usually made of glass.
riddle.explanation: A window allows you to see what's on the other side of a wall.

riddle.question: I am the classical dance of Kerala with dramatic makeup and costumes. What am I?
riddle.hint: Dancers use elaborate facial expressions.
riddle.explanation: Kathakali is a major form of classical Indian dance.

riddle.question: If I have it, I don’t share it. If I share it, I don’t have it. What is it?
riddle.hint: Only you and someone you trust know it.
riddle.explanation: A secret is only a secret as long as it isn't shared.

riddle.question: I am the epic Indian poem about the Kurukshetra War. What am I?
riddle.hint: It features the Bhagavad Gita.
riddle.explanation: The Mahabharata is one of the two major Sanskrit epics of ancient India.

riddle.question: What comes once in a minute, twice in a moment, but never in a thousand years?
riddle.hint: Look at the letters in the words themselves.
riddle.explanation: The letter 'M' appears in those words as described.

riddle.question: I am the ancient Indian university that was once a global center of learning in Bihar. What am I?
riddle.hint: Think of a world-famous Buddhist monastery.
riddle.explanation: Nalanda was a renowned Mahavihara in the ancient kingdom of Magadha.

riddle.question: The more you take, the more you leave behind. What am I?
riddle.hint: You leave these in the sand or snow as you walk.
riddle.explanation: As you walk, you take steps and leave footprints behind.

riddle.question: I am the Indian Nobel Laureate who wrote "Gitanjali". Who am I?
riddle.hint: He is the one who wrote India’s national anthem.
riddle.explanation: Tagore was the first non-European to win the Nobel Prize in Literature.

riddle.question: I have keys, but no locks. I have a space, but no room. You can enter, but you can’t leave. What am I?
riddle.hint: You use me to type on your computer.
riddle.explanation: A keyboard has 'Space' and 'Enter' keys.

riddle.question: I was an Indian king who turned to peace after the bloody war of Kalinga. Who am I?
riddle.hint: His name is associated with the Chakra on our flag.
riddle.explanation: Emperor Ashoka the Great embraced non-violence after seeing the horrors of war.

riddle.question: I am seen in water but never wet. What am I?
riddle.hint: I’m what you see when you look in a mirror.
riddle.explanation: A reflection in water is an image, not a physical wet object.

riddle.question: I am the first woman Prime Minister of India. Who am I?
riddle.hint: She was a powerful leader from the Nehru-Gandhi family.
riddle.explanation: Indira Gandhi served as Prime Minister for three consecutive terms.

riddle.question: What has a heart that doesn't beat?
riddle.hint: It’s a green, scaly vegetable.
riddle.explanation: An artichoke has a center called the "heart".

riddle.question: I am the Indian mathematical genius who had no formal training but solved complex theorems. Who am I?
riddle.hint: The number 1729 is famously associated with him.
riddle.explanation: Ramanujan made extraordinary contributions to mathematical analysis and number theory.

riddle.question: I have no voice, but I can talk to you. I have no legs, but I can travel with you. What am I?
riddle.hint: You read me to learn new things or hear stories.
riddle.explanation: A book communicates ideas and travels with the reader.

riddle.question: I am the world's highest statue, located in Gujarat, India. What is its name?
riddle.hint: It stands 182 meters tall near the Sardar Sarovar Dam.
riddle.explanation: The Statue of Unity is a 182-meter monumental statue of Sardar Patel.

riddle.question: What can fill an entire room but takes up no space?
riddle.hint: It comes from bulbs or the sun.
riddle.explanation: Light illuminates a room without occupying physical volume.

riddle.question: I am the Indian satellite mission that reached Mars on its first attempt. What is it called?
riddle.hint: This mission made India the 4th country to reach Mars.
riddle.explanation: Mars Orbiter Mission (MOM) made India the first nation to reach Mars on its maiden voyage.

riddle.question: What has a thumb but no fingers?
riddle.hint: You wear me in winter to keep your hand warm, but my shape is simpler than a glove.
riddle.explanation: A mitten has a separate space for the thumb and one for all fingers combined.

riddle.question: I am the Indian dance form from Andhra Pradesh, known for dancing on a brass plate. What am I?
riddle.hint: It's a classical dance often performed with a pot on the head.
riddle.explanation: Kuchipudi is a major classical Indian dance form originated in Krishna district.

riddle.question: If you drop me, I am sure to crack, but give me a smile and I will always smile back. What am I?
riddle.hint: I provide an exact reflection of what is in front of me.
riddle.explanation: A mirror is fragile and reflects your expression.

riddle.question: I am the first Indian woman to win an Olympic medal. Who am I?
riddle.hint: She won bronze in weightlifting at the Sydney 2000 games.
riddle.explanation: Malleswari won a bronze medal at the 2000 Sydney Olympics.

riddle.question: I fly without wings. I cry without eyes. What am I?
riddle.hint: I am floating in the sky and bring the rain.
riddle.explanation: Clouds move in the air (fly) and rain drops look like crying.

riddle.question: I am the Indian philosopher-monk who addressed the Parliament of Religions in Chicago, 1893. Who am I?
riddle.hint: He was a disciple of Sri Ramakrishna Paramahamsa.
riddle.explanation: Vivekananda introduced Indian philosophies of Vedanta and Yoga to the Western world.

riddle.question: What is black when you buy it, red when you use it, and gray when you throw it away?
riddle.hint: It's used for grilling or heating in traditional stoves.
riddle.explanation: Charcoal is black, glows red when burning, and turns to gray ash.

riddle.question: I am the Indian scientist who discovered why the sea looks blue. Who am I?
riddle.hint: The effect of light scattering is named after him.
riddle.explanation: Sir C.V. Raman won the Nobel Prize in Physics for his work on the scattering of light.

riddle.question: What can run but can't walk, has a mouth but can't talk, has a head but can't think, and has a bed but can't sleep?
riddle.hint: I flow continuously toward the ocean.
riddle.explanation: A river flows (runs), has a source (head), an opening (mouth), and a base (bed).

riddle.question: I am the "Birdman of India". I was a famous ornithologist. Who am I?
riddle.hint: His autobiography is titled "The Fall of a Sparrow".
riddle.explanation: Salim Ali was among the first Indians to conduct systematic bird surveys across India.

riddle.question: If an electric train is moving North at 100mph and a wind is blowing East at 10mph, which way does the smoke blow?
riddle.hint: Think about the propulsion system of the train.
riddle.explanation: Electric trains do not produce smoke.

riddle.question: I am the first Indian to win an individual Gold medal at the Olympics. Who am I?
riddle.hint: He won it for 10m Air Rifle shooting.
riddle.explanation: Bindra won the gold in Beijing 2008 in the 10m Air Rifle event.

riddle.question: What goes through towns and over hills, but never moves?
riddle.hint: It's what cars and buses travel on.
riddle.explanation: A road spans great distances but is fixed to the ground.

riddle.question: I am the Indian woman mountaineer who climbed Everest twice in one season. Who am I?
riddle.hint: She is from Arunachal Pradesh and set a world record.
riddle.explanation: Anshu Jamsenpa from Arunachal Pradesh holds the record for the fastest double ascent.

riddle.question: I am the only food that doesn't spoil. What am I?
riddle.hint: It’s sweet and made by bees.
riddle.explanation: Archaeologists have found edible honey in ancient Egyptian tombs.

riddle.question: I am the Indian state where the world's largest river island, Majuli, is located. What am I?
riddle.hint: The Brahmaputra river flows through here.
riddle.explanation: Majuli is a lush green river island in the Brahmaputra River.

riddle.question: What has many needles, but can’t sew?
riddle.hint: I am an animal with spikes all over my back.
riddle.explanation: A porcupine's quills are often referred to as needles.

riddle.question: I am the Indian king of the Maratha Empire, known for guerrilla warfare. Who am I?
riddle.hint: He was born in Shivneri Fort and built a strong navy.
riddle.explanation: Shivaji Maharaj founded the Maratha Empire and pioneered guerrilla tactics.

riddle.question: What starts with an E, ends with an E, but only contains one letter?
riddle.hint: You need me to send a card through the post.
riddle.explanation: An envelope contains a "letter" (mail).

riddle.question: I am the "Missile Man of India". I was the 11th President. Who am I?
riddle.hint: He loved children and was a key scientist for Pokhran-II.
riddle.explanation: Dr. Kalam was a scientist and statesman known for his role in India's missile program.

riddle.question: I have no mass, yet I carry energy. I travel at the speed of light, but I am not a wave. What am I?
riddle.hint: I am a particle of light.
riddle.explanation: Photons are the basic units of light and carry electromagnetic force.

riddle.question: I am the largest salt lake in India, located in Rajasthan. What am I?
riddle.hint: It’s near Jaipur and is an important source of salt.
riddle.explanation: Sambhar Salt Lake is India's largest inland salt lake.

riddle.question: What stays where it is when it goes off?
riddle.hint: It rings to wake you up in the morning.
riddle.explanation: An alarm clock "goes off" (rings) but stays on your table.

riddle.question: I am the first Indian woman to win the Miss World title. Who am I?
riddle.hint: She reached the top in 1966.
riddle.explanation: Reita Faria Powell became the first Indian and Asian to win Miss World.

riddle.question: What can be seen once in a year, twice in a week, and never in a day?
riddle.hint: Examine the spelling of 'year', 'week', and 'day'.
riddle.explanation: The letter 'E' appears in those words as described.

riddle.question: I am the holy book of the Sikhs, located in the Golden Temple. What am I?
riddle.hint: It's the eternal living Guru of the Sikh community.
riddle.explanation: The Guru Granth Sahib is the central religious scripture of Sikhism.
